entry.title: Combined summary - BIP - 'Block75' - New algorithm
entry.summary: The email conversation among cryptocurrency experts revolves around the topic of block size limit and whether or not Block75 algorithm could solve the problems related to miner spam and growth in resource requirements. On January 2, 2017, t. khan via bitcoin-dev proposed a change to the maximum block size, not the block size itself. The proposal suggested that miners should have full control over the maximum block size since they ultimately decide on the actual created block size. However, the proposal is criticized for giving miners complete control over the limit, which defeats the purpose of the block size limit. Luke Dashjr argues that using the growth rate over the last year as a model, Block75 would frequently decrease the limit, but the entire point of this is to allow for larger blocks over time with more transactions. However, t.k. points out that this does not solve the actual problems of either miner spam or growth in resource requirements, which are the entire purpose of the block size limit.The discussion revolves around the Bitcoin protocol and its block size limit. The proposal of Block75 is to manage the maximum block size without human intervention, rather than allowing miners to have direct control. Under this system, miners can still choose to mine smaller blocks if they wish, but it will cost them in terms of fees from transactions that were not included in their blocks. The purpose of a maximum block size is to prevent a single nefarious miner from creating an overly large block that could potentially break the network. Tom Zander responded to this proposal, questioning why miners cannot simply be given full control of the maximum block size directly, as they have had this control throughout the history of Bitcoin. He also wondered why there should be a maximum block size in the protocol at all. Luke Dashjr suggested that an ever-increasing block size limit would be equivalent to spam filling blocks up to the max and miners not enforcing reasonable limits. The discussion also focuses on whether a maximum block size limit should be part of the protocol or just a policy set by node operators. It is argued that if a block is rejected based on a condition, then it is considered part of the consensus protocol. Policies are things that can vary from node to node without affecting the validity judgement of blocks.The writer argues that the block size limit is set by miners and not math, despite everything in Bitcoin being math-based. They suggest a proposal where the maximum block size continues to be set by miners as a secondary effect of them choosing the block size. The other person suggests that a simple policy set by node operators could solve this issue. However, the writer disagrees and believes it would be an epic disaster since there's no such thing as a "simple policy" when humans are involved.Overall, the discussion highlights the importance of miners in determining the block size limit in Bitcoin and how their behavior is influenced by economics. The Block75 algorithm has been updated based on feedback from the community and further simulations. The new algorithm aims to keep blocks 75% full by increasing the maximum block size by a certain percentage, calculated using the current maximum block size, average percentage full of the last 201 blocks, and other factors.Although there might be a long-term incentive to increase the blocksize, it comes with a cost. Miners have to plan for the short term as well, which makes it irrational for them to spam their blocks with their own transactions or low fee transactions to increase the blocksize limit. The context discusses the control of miners over the limit, which can be increased by making blocks of any size. The proposal to raise the limit further can be triggered with this feature.
